verses.verse: He began teaching again by the sea shore and a great multitude gathered near him, so he got into a ship and sat in the sea while the whole multitude was next to the sea on land.
He taught them many things by parables and said to them in his teaching,
"Listen closely! Behold, a sower of seed went out to sow,
and it happened, as he sowed, some fell by the roadside and the birds of the air came and ate it up.
"Some fell on stony ground where it didn't have much dirt; immediately it sprang up, because he wasn't deep enough in the dirt,
and when the sun was up, it got scorched, and because it had no root it withered away.
"Some fell among thorns, and the thorns grew up and choked it; it yielded no fruit.
"Others fell on good ground and yielded fruit that sprang up and increased. It brought forth some thirty, some sixty, and some a hundred."
And he said to them, "He who has ears to hear, you better hear."
When he was alone, those who were around him along with the twelve asked him about the parable.
And he said to them, "To you it is given to know the mystery about the Kingdom of God, but to those who are outside, all these things come [to them] in parables,
so that seeing they see, yet not really see, and hearing they hear, yet not understand, so perhaps they should be converted and their sins should be forgiven them."
And he said to them, "Don't you see what this parable means? So how will you understand any parable?
"The sower of seed sows the word.
"These are those who are by the roadside where the word is sown, but when they have heard, Satan immediately comes and takes away the word that was sown in their hearts.
"These are sown on stony ground, who, when they heard the word, immediately receive it with joy,
yet have no root in themselves and only endure a short time. Afterward when distress or persecution arises for the word's sake, immediately they are offended.
"These are those who are sown among thorns, they hear the word,
but the distractions of this world, deceitfulness of riches, and lusts of other things entering in choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
"These are those who sown on good ground, they hear the word, receive it, and bring forth fruit, some thirty fold, some sixty, and some a hundred."
And he said to them, "Is a candle brought out to be put under a basket or under a bed, isn't it to be set on a candlestick?
"For there is nothing hid which will not be clearly seen, neither anything be kept secret, but that it will be widely known.
"If any one has ears, you better hear."
And he said to them, "Watch what you hear; [for] with what you measure, it will be measured to you, and to you who hear will more be given.
"For he who has, to him will be given, and he who doesn't have, from him will taken even that what he has."
And he said, "So the Kingdom of God is as if a man should scatter seed on the ground,
and should sleep at night and rise at day, and the seed sprout and grow up, [but] he doesn't know how.
"For the earth brings forth fruit by itself; first the blade, then the ear, after that the full of grain in the ear.
"And when the fruit is ready to yield, immediately he sends out the sickle, because the harvest stands ready."
And he said, "To what will we compare the Kingdom of God or to what likeness will we liken it?
"It is like a grain of mustard seed, which when it is sown in the ground, is least of all the seeds that are in the ground,
but when it is sown, grows up, and becomes greater than all herbs, and shoots out great branches, so that the birds of the air may roost under its shadow."
And with many such parables he spoke the word to them, as much as they were able to understand.
But outside of parables he didn't speak to them, but when they were alone, he explained all to his disciples.
That same day, when evening came, he said to them, "Let us go over to the other side."
And when they had sent away the multitude, they took him, since he was in the ship. There were also other little ships with him.
Then a huge windstorm rose up, and the waves beat on the ship, so that it was now entirely full.
But he was in the back of the ship asleep on a cushion, and they woke him up and said to him, "Master, aren't you concerned that we are dying?"
He got up and rebuked the wind and said to the sea, "Peace, be still." Then the wind stopped, and there was a great calm.
He said to them, "Why are you so afraid; how is it that you have no faith?"
And they were extremely afraid and said to one another, "What kind of man is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?"
